description: A hearty and flavorful stew where the distinct, slightly bitter taste of Jobyo (Acanthus) leaves is perfectly balanced by a thick, creamy, and nutty groundnut sauce. The robust greens hold their texture well in the rich sauce, creating a deeply satisfying and nutrient-dense dish that is a beloved comfort food in Northern Uganda.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: This dish is a classic example of Ugandan culinary wisdom, combining a foraged wild vegetable with a staple protein source. The groundnut sauce transforms the sometimes challenging bitterness of Jobyo into a beloved and accessible dish. It is a common meal in households, providing essential nutrients from locally available ingredients. Preparing Jobyo in groundnut sauce is a way to make a nutritious wild green more palatable and enjoyable for the whole family, especially children.

ingredients.name: Fresh Jobyo Leaves (Acanthus)
ingredients.notes: About 10-12 cups, young tender leaves are best. Washed thoroughly and chopped.

ingredients.name: Baking Soda
ingredients.notes: A tiny pinch to help soften the Jobyo leaves and reduce bitterness.

steps.instruction: Bring 2 cups of water to a boil in a large pot. Add the pinch of baking soda and the chopped Jobyo leaves.
Boil the Jobyo leaves for 5-7 minutes until tender and the initial bitterness is reduced. Drain the water and set the leaves aside.

cooking_indicators.visual: Leaves become a darker green and are soft to the touch.

steps.instruction: In the same pot, add the chopped onion and 1/2 cup of water. Cook over medium heat until the onion is soft and translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add the chopped tomato and cook for another 5 minutes until it softens and breaks down into a sauce.
In a separate bowl, gradually whisk the groundnut paste with 1.5 cups of water until you have a very smooth, lump-free, creamy liquid.
Pour the smooth groundnut mixture into the pot with the tomato and onion base. Stir to combine.
Bring the sauce to a gentle simmer. Let it cook for 5-10 minutes, stirring frequently to prevent burning, until it thickens slightly.
Add the pre-boiled Jobyo leaves and salt to the pot. Stir well to coat the leaves in the sauce.
Reduce the heat to low, cover, and let it simmer for another 10 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld and the Jobyo to fully absorb the nutty flavor. Stir occasionally.

cooking_indicators.texture: The sauce should be thick and creamy, coating the leaves thoroughly. The Jobyo should be tender but not mushy.

steps.instruction: If the stew is too thick, add a little more hot water to reach your desired consistency. Taste and adjust salt if needed. Serve hot.

serving_suggestions: Serve as a main dish with a staple carbohydrate like Posho (Ugali), Millet Bread (Kalo), or Cassava. The thick, rich sauce is perfect for scooping. It can also be served with steamed rice or sweet potatoes.
